title: 113_hr4861
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission for Our Veterans' Care Act" and establishes a Commission on Access to Care. The Commission on Access to Care is established with voting members appointed by the President, including representation for veterans and experts in hospital systems. The Commission on Access to Care, established with voting members appointed by the President, includes experts from the private insurance industry and individuals familiar with the Veterans Health Administration. Nonvoting members represent organizations recognized for veteran representation. The Commission on Access to Care, established with members appointed by the President, includes experts from public and private hospital systems, the private insurance industry, and the Veterans Health Administration. Appointments must be made within 60 days of the Act's enactment, and members serve for the life of the Commission. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled promptly. The Commission on Access to Care, appointed by the President, evaluates health care access at the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Commission's powers are unaffected by vacancies, and meetings are called by the Chairperson. A majority of members constitutes a quorum for meetings. The Commission on Access to Care evaluates current standards of health care access at the Department of Veterans Affairs, including measurement, performance standards, incentives, and staffing levels. Reports are submitted to the President through the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The Commission on Access to Care, through the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, submits an interim report within 90 days and a final report within 180 days of its initial meeting. The reports include findings on evaluation and assessment, along with recommendations for legislative or administrative actions to enhance health care access through the Veterans Health Administration. The Commission may hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and make recommendations for improving access to health care through the Veterans Health Administration. The Commission, upon request of the Chairperson, can obtain information from federal departments or agencies. Members of the Commission receive compensation based on their status as government employees or officials. The Commission members are allowed travel expenses and per diem while performing services. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to set compensation for the executive director and staff without following certain federal pay regulations. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement and without losing their civil service status. The Commission may procure temporary services at specified rates and will terminate 30 days after submitting its report. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will provide funding for the Commission's duties. The President is required to implement feasible and advisable recommendations from reports submitted by the Commission on Veterans' Affairs without further legislative action. Reports must be submitted to relevant committees of Congress within 60 days of receiving the report. The President must submit a report to Congress assessing the feasibility and advisability of recommendations from the Commission on Veterans' Affairs. For feasible recommendations requiring legislative action, a recommendation for such action must be included, along with any administrative steps already taken. The President must report to Congress on recommendations from the Commission on Veterans' Affairs, including any administrative actions to be taken.
